sections.title: Investment Planning Framework
sections.content: Effective investment planning starts with clearly defined goals, time horizons, and risk tolerance. Your asset allocation should reflect these factors and be designed to achieve your objectives while managing risk. Regular monitoring and rebalancing ensure your portfolio stays aligned with your plan.

points.title: Define Goals and Time Horizon
points.description: Short-term goals (1-3 years) need stability; long-term goals (10+ years) can tolerate more volatility.

points.title: Assess Risk Tolerance
points.description: Consider both your ability to take risk (financial situation) and willingness to take risk (emotional tolerance).

points.title: Develop Asset Allocation
points.description: Choose an appropriate mix of stocks, bonds, and alternatives based on your goals and risk profile.

sections.title: Asset Allocation Drives Returns
sections.content: Studies show that 90%+ of investment returns are determined by asset allocation, not individual security selection or market timing.

sections.title: Strategic vs. Tactical Allocation
sections.content: Strategic allocation sets long-term targets based on your goals and risk tolerance. Tactical allocation makes short-term adjustments based on market conditions. Most individual investors benefit from strategic allocation with periodic rebalancing to maintain target allocations.

sections.title: Create Your Investment Plan
steps: List your financial goals with time horizons and required returns
Complete a risk tolerance questionnaire to determine your profile
Develop a target asset allocation that matches your goals and risk tolerance
Select specific investments and set up automatic contributions and rebalancing

sections.title: Keep It Simple
sections.content: Start with a simple two-fund or three-fund portfolio using low-cost index funds. Add complexity only as your knowledge and portfolio size grow.
